did.unittitle:
C. Willett Spooner visual materials collection
1957-1960

physdesc.extent: 2 film reels (8mm, 550 ft.) with DVD use copy and streaming file

did.abstract: Films, DVD use copies and streaming files the construction of the Great Lakes freighter Edmund Fitzgerald, the launchings of the freighters Herbert C. Jackson and Arthur B. Homer, and the maiden voyage of the Homer. These freighters were the last ships built by Great Lakes Engineering Works, River Rouge, Michigan

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of C. Willett Spooner (donor no. 8130).

accruals.p: No further additions to the collection are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research. The original 8mm films are restricted, DVD use copy and streaming file available.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, C. Willett Spooner visual materials collection, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: C. Willett Spooner was professor in the Department of Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering at the University of Michigan. In the late 1950s, he left the university in order to work in private industry. Perhaps in this connection, he was able to obtain these motion pictures relating to the construction of freighters by the Great Lakes Engineering Works of River Rouge, Michigan.

scopecontent.p: The Spooner collection consists of two motion pictures (with DVD use copy) of the construction of the Great Lakes freighter Edmund Fitzgerald, the launchings of the freighters Herbert C. Jackson and Arthur B. Homer, and the maiden voyage of the Homer. These freighters were the last ships built by Great Lakes Engineering Works of River Rouge, Michigan.
In 2009 a preservation tape, DVD use copy and master and streaming digital files of the motion pictures were made.

did.unittitle: Launchings of the freighters Herbert C. Jackson and Arthur B. Homer, and the maiden voyage of the Homer, 1959-1960
